sourceAuthority.description: Prioritize sources based on authority and reliability
sourceAuthority.whenToUse: When sources have different levels of authority or credibility
approach: Prioritize authoritative sources (academic, official, reputable organizations)
Consider source expertise and domain authority
Prefer recent sources from established institutions
Acknowledge when using authority-based prioritization
sourceAuthority.example: When a government report conflicts with a blog post, prioritize the government report but acknowledge both sources exist.

recency.description: Prioritize more recent information when sources conflict
recency.whenToUse: When information changes over time or sources are from different time periods
approach: Prioritize more recent sources when information is time-sensitive
Acknowledge that information may have changed
Note the time difference between sources
Use recent information but mention older perspectives if relevant
recency.example: When a 2020 study conflicts with a 2024 study, prioritize the 2024 study but note that the 2020 study may have been valid at that time.

consensus.description: Present multiple perspectives when sources conflict
consensus.whenToUse: When multiple credible sources have different views and no clear authority exists
approach: Present both perspectives fairly
Cite each perspective with its source
Acknowledge the disagreement
Explain why there might be disagreement
Avoid taking sides when both are credible
consensus.example: When two reputable studies have different conclusions, present both perspectives with their sources and acknowledge the disagreement.

contextualRelevance.description: Prioritize sources most relevant to the specific context
contextualRelevance.whenToUse: When sources address different contexts or scopes
approach: Prioritize sources most directly relevant to the question
Consider geographic, temporal, or domain-specific context
Acknowledge when context affects applicability
Note limitations of sources to specific contexts
contextualRelevance.example: When a US-specific study conflicts with a global study, prioritize based on the question's context (US vs. global).

evidenceStrength.description: Prioritize sources with stronger evidence or methodology
evidenceStrength.whenToUse: When sources have different levels of evidence quality
approach: Prioritize sources with stronger methodology
Consider sample size, study design, and evidence quality
Acknowledge methodological differences
Note limitations of weaker evidence
evidenceStrength.example: When a peer-reviewed study conflicts with an anecdotal report, prioritize the peer-reviewed study but acknowledge both exist.

acknowledgeConflict.example: Sources provide conflicting information about this topic. [Source A](url) states X, while [Source B](url) states Y.

requirements: Give equal weight to both perspectives when both are credible
Cite each perspective with its source
Explain the nature of the disagreement
presentBothPerspectives.example: There are different perspectives on this issue. According to [Source A](url), the approach is X. However, [Source B](url) suggests Y. Both perspectives have merit.

prioritizeWithExplanation.description: When prioritizing one source, explain why
requirements: Clearly state which source is being prioritized
Explain the reason for prioritization (authority, recency, evidence, etc.)
prioritizeWithExplanation.example: While [Source A](url) suggests X, [Source B](url) (a more recent study from 2024) indicates Y. Based on recency, Y is more likely accurate.

avoidSpeculation.description: Don't speculate about which source is correct
requirements: Avoid guessing which source is right
Don't make unsupported claims about source accuracy
Present facts and let the user decide when appropriate
avoidSpeculation.example: Sources conflict on this point. [Source A](url) states X, while [Source B](url) states Y. Without additional information, it's unclear which is accurate.

whenToAcknowledge.limitedSources: When only one source is available and it may not be comprehensive
whenToAcknowledge.outdatedInformation: When sources are old and information may have changed
whenToAcknowledge.methodologicalLimitations: When sources have limitations in methodology or scope
whenToAcknowledge.incompleteInformation: When sources don't fully address the question
whenToAcknowledge.ambiguousInformation: When information is unclear or open to interpretation

explicitStatements: Use phrases like 'sources conflict', 'information is unclear', 'may vary', 'uncertain'
Cite sources even when acknowledging uncertainty
examples: Sources provide conflicting information about this topic. [Source A](url) suggests X, while [Source B](url) suggests Y.
The available information is limited. Based on [Source A](url), X appears to be the case, but this may not be comprehensive.
Information on this topic may have changed since the source was published. [Source A](url) from 2020 indicates X, but more recent information may differ.

conflictExample1.conflict: Source A says 50%, Source B says 60%
conflictExample1.resolution: Sources provide different statistics for this metric. [Source A](url) reports 50%, while [Source B](url) reports 60%. The difference may be due to different methodologies, time periods, or sample populations. Both sources are cited for transparency.

conflictExample2.scenario: Recent source conflicts with older source
conflictExample2.conflict: 2020 study says X, 2024 study says Y
conflictExample2.resolution: Information on this topic has evolved. A 2020 study [Source A](url) indicated X, but a more recent 2024 study [Source B](url) suggests Y. Based on recency, Y is more likely accurate, though X may have been valid at the time.

conflictExample3.scenario: Authoritative source conflicts with less authoritative source
conflictExample3.conflict: Government report says X, blog post says Y
conflictExample3.resolution: Sources provide conflicting information. The government report [Source A](url) states X, while a blog post [Source B](url) suggests Y. Given the authoritative nature of the government report, X is prioritized, though Y is noted for completeness.

conflictExample4.scenario: Multiple credible sources with different perspectives
conflictExample4.conflict: Three reputable studies have different conclusions
conflictExample4.resolution: There are different perspectives on this issue. Study A [Source A](url) concludes X, Study B [Source B](url) suggests Y, and Study C [Source C](url) indicates Z. All three studies are from reputable sources, and the disagreement may reflect different methodologies or contexts.

uncertaintyExample1.situation: Single source, may not be comprehensive
uncertaintyExample1.acknowledgment: Based on the available source [Source A](url), X appears to be the case. However, information is limited to this single source, and additional sources may provide more comprehensive information.

uncertaintyExample2.situation: Source is from 2018, information may have changed
uncertaintyExample2.acknowledgment: According to [Source A](url) from 2018, X was the case. However, information may have changed since then, and more recent sources may provide updated information.

uncertaintyExample3.situation: Source information is unclear or open to interpretation
uncertaintyExample3.acknowledgment: The source [Source A](url) provides information that is somewhat ambiguous. It suggests X, but this may be open to interpretation or may depend on specific circumstances.

transparency: Explain why you're prioritizing one source
fairness: Give equal weight when both are credible
userEmpowerment: Present information so users can make informed decisions
Don't make decisions for users when sources conflict
Provide enough context for users to evaluate
sourceAttribution: Make it clear which source says what

ignoringConflicts.correct: Always acknowledge conflicts and present both perspectives

example.correct: Sources provide conflicting information. [Source A](url) states X, while [Source B](url) states Y.

takingSides.mistake: Taking sides without explanation when both sources are credible
takingSides.correct: Present both perspectives fairly or explain why one is prioritized

example.wrong: X is correct. [Source A](url) Y is wrong.
example.correct: There are different perspectives. [Source A](url) suggests X, while [Source B](url) suggests Y. Both are from credible sources.

speculating.mistake: Speculating about which source is correct without evidence
speculating.correct: Acknowledge uncertainty and present both perspectives

example.wrong: Source A is probably right because it seems more logical.
example.correct: Sources conflict. [Source A](url) states X, while [Source B](url) states Y. Without additional evidence, it's unclear which is accurate.

mergingConflicts.mistake: Merging conflicting information into a single statement
mergingConflicts.correct: Present conflicts separately with clear source attribution

example.wrong: The answer is between X and Y. [Source A](url) [Source B](url)
example.correct: Sources provide different information. [Source A](url) states X, while [Source B](url) states Y.

beforeSubmission: Check for any conflicting information in sources
